Vigencia is specific to norms, laws, agreements — an idea or trend uses 'vigencia' more loosely
Over-nominalization can obscure meaning — use judiciously for formal effect, not as a default
examples: La aprobación de esta normativa tendrá repercusiones significativas en el sector financiero. (The approval of this regulation will have significant repercussions for the financial sector.)
La incidencia de ciberataques en el sector público ha aumentado un 40% en el último año. (The incidence of cyberattacks in the public sector has increased by 40% in the past year.)

La prevalencia de este modelo de negocio en mercados emergentes plantea interrogantes sobre su sostenibilidad. (The prevalence of this business model in emerging markets raises questions about its sustainability.)
Dicho acuerdo perderá su vigencia a partir del próximo 31 de diciembre. (Said agreement will cease to be in force from 31 December.)
La implementación de las medidas acordadas se llevará a cabo de forma escalonada. (The implementation of the agreed measures will be carried out in a phased manner. — nominalization)

Verbs of Clarification/Unraveling (desen.rule: Spanish has a cluster of formal verbs for different types of 'clarifying', 'uncovering', or 'explaining'. They differ in the nature of what is being clarified and the degree of complexity/effort involved. C1/C2 precision requires selecting the right verb for the type of knowledge being revealed.
Verbs of Clarification/Unraveling (desen.structure: Subject + verb + direct object (the thing being clarified/uncovered)
formation: All regular or standard conjugation patterns
Desentrañar: to unravel/disentangle (complex, deeply embedded content — requires effort)
Dilucidar: to elucidate/clarify (to shed light on, resolve ambiguity — academic/formal)
Desvelar: to unveil/reveal (to make known something previously hidden or unknown)
Esclarecer: to clarify/shed light on (general formal clarification)
Aclarar: neutral general clarification; less formal than esclarecer
uses: Desentrañar: for hidden, complex, deeply layered content: 'desentrañar el significado de un texto', 'desentrañar los mecanismos del fraude'
Dilucidar: academic/investigative; 'dilucidar las causas de un fenómeno', 'dilucidar si X es verdad'
Desvelar: journalistic/dramatic; reveal something previously concealed: 'desvelar la identidad', 'desvelar el escándalo'
Esclarecer: neutral formal clarification of a confused situation: 'esclarecer los hechos', 'esclarecer responsabilidades'
Descifrar: decode/decipher — for coded or cryptic content: 'descifrar un mensaje', 'descifrar las intenciones'
notes: Desentrañar implies the object is complex and tangled — it's not used for simple clarification
Desvelar has a dramatic/revelatory flavor — often used in journalism for exposés
Dilucidar is preferred in academic/scientific writing for resolving theoretical questions
Esclarecer and aclarar overlap but esclarecer is more formal and implies broader context
Descifrar is for genuinely cryptic or coded content; using it for simple clarification is too strong
examples: El análisis forense permitió desentrañar los mecanismos del fraude contable. (The forensic analysis made it possible to unravel the mechanisms of the accounting fraud.)
Los investigadores aún no han logrado dilucidar las causas exactas del accidente. (Researchers have still not managed to elucidate the exact causes of the accident.)
La investigación periodística desveló la existencia de cuentas bancarias ocultas en paraísos fiscales. (The journalistic investigation revealed the existence of hidden bank accounts in tax havens.)
El informe pericial contribuyó a esclarecer las responsabilidades de cada parte. (The expert report helped to clarify the responsibilities of each party.)
Fue imposible descifrar las verdaderas intenciones del negociador durante las conversaciones. (It was impossible to decipher the negotiator's true intentions during the talks.)

Verbs of Entailment/Causation (conllevar.rule: Formal Spanish uses precise verbs to express that one thing entails, causes, or brings about another. These are not interchangeable: 'conllevar' emphasizes inherent logical entailment; 'acarrear' stresses negative or undesirable consequences; 'comportar' (legal/technical) implies an obligatory result or condition attached to something; 'implicar' covers logical implication broadly; 'suponer' means 'to represent/amount to' in formal contexts.
formation: All regular -ar or -er verbs in standard conjugations
Conllevar: takes a noun or infinitive object
Acarrear: takes a noun object (consequences, problems, risks)
Comportar: takes a noun object; mostly legal/technical register
Implicar: broadest — takes noun or que + subjunctive
Suponer: 'to represent/amount to' in formal use (not just 'to suppose')
uses: Conllevar: 'Esta decisión conlleva riesgos importantes' — the risks are inherent, attached, unavoidable
Acarrear: 'Su negligencia acarreó graves consecuencias' — negative consequences as a result
Comportar: 'El incumplimiento comporta la rescisión automática' — legal/contractual entailment
Suponer: 'Esto supone un avance significativo' — amounts to / represents (formal sense)
Implicar: broad logical implication: 'Esto implica que debemos reconsiderar nuestra estrategia'
notes: Acarrear almost always has negative connotation — do not use for neutral or positive entailments
Comportar is mainly legal/technical — rarely heard in general conversation
Conllevar is the most versatile of the group; negative, neutral, or even positive entailments
Suponer in this formal sense ≠ 'to suppose/assume' — context distinguishes ('supone un coste de X euros')
examples: La adopción de este nuevo marco regulatorio conlleva obligaciones adicionales para las empresas del sector. (The adoption of this new regulatory framework entails additional obligations for sector companies.)
Su falta de diligencia acarreó consecuencias nefastas para toda la organización. (His lack of diligence brought about disastrous consequences for the entire organisation.)
El incumplimiento de las condiciones estipuladas comportará la resolución inmediata del contrato. (Failure to meet the stipulated conditions will entail the immediate termination of the contract.)
Este hallazgo supone un avance fundamental en la comprensión de la enfermedad. (This finding represents a fundamental advance in understanding the disease.)
Aceptar estas condiciones implicaría renunciar a derechos previamente adquiridos. (Accepting these conditions would imply giving up previously acquired rights.)

Adjectives of Obviousness (palmaria, pat.rule: Spanish has a rich set of formal adjectives meaning 'obvious/evident' with distinct nuances of register and connotation. C1/C2 precision requires selecting the right adjective for the context. These appear frequently in legal, academic, and journalistic writing.
formation: All regular adjective agreement: -o/-a/-os/-as or invariable
Patente: always follows ser/resultar/quedar or precedes noun — no change of form for gender
Manifiesta/manifiesto: agrees with noun gender
Flagrante: from Latin; used mainly in legal/criminal contexts, often in set phrases
Palmaria/palmario: formal, mainly predicative
uses: Patente: clear, plainly visible, beyond dispute — formal/academic: 'queda patente que...'
Manifiesto/a: openly evident, not hidden — often collocates with 'poner de manifiesto': 'su incompetencia resultó manifiesta'
Flagrante: caught in the act; highly negative and legal: 'flagrante violación de derechos', 'infracción flagrante'; set phrase 'in flagrante'
Palmario/a: very formal/literary for irrefutable clarity: 'es una verdad palmaria'
Ostensible: visible/apparent — sometimes used where a less dramatic word is needed; has slight connotation of 'ostentatious'
notes: Flagrante is ALMOST ALWAYS used in negative/condemning contexts — do not use for positive evidence
Poner de manifiesto is a fixed formal expression: 'el informe pone de manifiesto las deficiencias'
Palmario is the most elevated; using it conversationally would sound stiff
Patente and manifiesto are the most commonly used in academic prose
Ostensible can be ambiguous: 'ostensible mejora' may read as 'apparent (but not real) improvement'
examples: La investigación pone de manifiesto la existencia de irregularidades sistemáticas. (The investigation reveals the existence of systematic irregularities. — poner de manifiesto = fixed expression)
Es patente que el sistema de supervisión ha fallado en su función preventiva. (It is clear that the supervisory system has failed in its preventive function.)

La resolución judicial calificó los hechos de flagrante vulneración del derecho a la tutela efectiva. (The judicial ruling classified the events as a flagrant violation of the right to effective judicial protection.)
Su falta de preparación resultó manifiesta desde el primer momento de la comparecencia. (His lack of preparation was plainly evident from the first moment of the hearing.)
Es una verdad palmaria que sin inversión en educación no puede existir desarrollo sostenible. (It is a self-evident truth that without investment in education, sustainable development cannot exist.)

Verbs of Revelation/Disclosure.rule: Formal Spanish distinguishes between verbs for different types of making something known: revealing hidden information (desvelar, revelar), demonstrating/evidencing (demostrar, evidenciar, acreditar), and formally confirming (constatar, corroborar, certificar). Register and agency matter: some imply active disclosure, others passive emergence of truth.
formation: All standard conjugations; reflexive variants possible for some (revelarse como)
uses: Desvelar: dramatic revelation of previously hidden information (journalistic, exposé)
Revelar: broader — reveal, disclose; also used in scientific/academic contexts
Evidenciar: the evidence shows/demonstrates — often impersonal: 'los datos evidencian que...'
Constatar: to establish/verify as fact after observation: 'se constató que...'
Corroborar: to corroborate/confirm with additional evidence: 'estos datos corroboran la hipótesis'
Acreditar: formal/legal; to prove/establish officially: 'acreditar la identidad', 'acreditar méritos'
notes: Desvelar is more dramatic than revelar — journalistic exposés prefer desvelar
Constatar implies a direct observational or evidentiary basis — more scientific than revelar
Corroborar always implies secondary supporting evidence confirming something already claimed
Acreditar has a specifically formal/legal register — it implies official documentation or proof
examples: Los documentos filtrados desvelaron la existencia de acuerdos secretos entre los gobiernos. (The leaked documents revealed the existence of secret agreements between the governments.)
Los datos estadísticos evidencian una correlación entre desigualdad económica y conflictividad social. (Statistical data evidences a correlation between economic inequality and social conflict.)
La auditoría constató irregularidades en la gestión de los fondos públicos. (The audit established irregularities in the management of public funds.)
Los nuevos testimonios corroboran la versión ofrecida por el principal testigo. (The new testimonies corroborate the version offered by the main witness.)
El candidato deberá acreditar el dominio del idioma mediante certificado oficial. (The candidate must officially prove language proficiency through an official certificate.)

Verbs of Dispute Resolution (dirimir, za.rule: Formal Spanish has specific verbs for resolving disputes, conflicts, or problems. 'Dirimir' is highly formal/legal and used almost exclusively for disputes, controversies, and conflicts between parties. 'Zanjar' conveys a definitive, often abrupt end to a disagreement. 'Solventar' applies to solving practical problems or difficulties. 'Resolver' is the most general.
formation: All standard conjugations; dirimir follows regular -ir pattern
uses: Dirimir: legal/formal — resolving disputes, controversies, differences of interpretation: 'dirimir una controversia', 'dirimir competencias'
Zanjar: cutting short / definitively closing: 'zanjar la discusión', 'zanjar el asunto' — implies finality, sometimes brusqueness
Solventar: solving practical difficulties or obstacles: 'solventar un problema técnico', 'solventar las deudas'
Resolver: neutral/general; applies to problems, conflicts, equations — broadest use
Dirimir diferencias/disputas/controversias: almost always collocates with these nouns
notes: Dirimir is NOT interchangeable with resolver in everyday language — it is exclusively formal/legal
Zanjar implies the matter is closed once and for all — it cannot be reopened: 'zanjar el debate'
Solventar focuses on eliminating an obstacle or settling a debt/difficulty — not for abstract disputes
In legal texts, 'dirimir' is frequently found with 'conflictos de competencia' and 'controversias'
examples: Corresponde al Tribunal Constitucional dirimir los conflictos de competencia entre el Estado y las comunidades autónomas. (It is for the Constitutional Court to resolve competence conflicts between the State and the autonomous communities.)
La mediación logró zanjar definitivamente el litigio sin necesidad de recurrir a los tribunales. (The mediation managed to definitively settle the litigation without the need to go to court.)
El equipo técnico consiguió solventar los problemas de infraestructura antes del plazo previsto. (The technical team managed to resolve the infrastructure problems before the anticipated deadline.)
Las partes acordaron dirimir sus diferencias mediante arbitraje internacional. (The parties agreed to resolve their differences through international arbitration.)

Verbs of Fostering/Promoting.rule: Formal Spanish uses distinct verbs for encouraging or fostering something depending on the degree of active intervention and the nature of what is being promoted. 'Fomentar' suggests active cultivation/encouragement of a desirable process; 'impulsar' implies giving momentum/drive; 'promover' is formal for initiating or promoting; 'favorecer' means to favor/facilitate; 'propiciar' means to create conditions for.
formation: All standard conjugations
uses: Fomentar: sustained encouragement of a positive process: 'fomentar la innovación', 'fomentar la cooperación'
Impulsar: give drive/momentum to something: 'impulsar el crecimiento', 'impulsar una reforma'
Promover: formally initiate or advocate for: 'promover una ley', 'promover el diálogo'
Favorecer: create favorable conditions: 'la reforma favorece la inversión'
Propiciar: create circumstances that make something more likely: 'propiciar un clima de confianza'
notes: Fomentar is the most common in institutional/policy language for desired positive development
Impulsar implies energy and momentum — often used for stalled processes given a push
Propiciar is subtler — it creates conditions rather than directly causing: 'propicia pero no garantiza'
Promover overlaps with 'fomentar' but has a more initiatory connotation
examples: El programa tiene como objetivo fomentar la cultura emprendedora entre los jóvenes. (The programme aims to foster an entrepreneurial culture among young people.)
Es necesario impulsar medidas que agilicen los trámites administrativos. (It is necessary to drive forward measures that streamline administrative procedures.)
La nueva política fiscal propicia un entorno más favorable para la inversión extranjera. (The new fiscal policy creates conditions more favorable to foreign investment.)
El acuerdo busca promover la transferencia de tecnología entre los países participantes. (The agreement seeks to promote technology transfer between the participating countries.)

Legal Verbs (permission, prohibition, ob.rule: Legal Spanish uses specialized verbs for expressing permission, prohibition, and obligation that go beyond standard 'poder', 'no poder', and 'tener que'. These verbs appear in legislation, contracts, and formal administrative texts and carry specific legal force.
Legal Verbs (permission, prohibition, ob.structure: Modal legal verb + infinitive | Legal verb + que + subjunctive
formation: Permission: autorizar a, facultar para, habilitar para, permitir (with legal force)
Prohibition: vedar, prohibir, proscribir, interdictar
Obligation: prescribir, estipular, preceptuar, establecer, disponer
Stipulation/definition: definir como, calificar de, tipificar como
uses: Vedar: to forbid/bar — more absolute than prohibir; often in formal/constitutional contexts: 'queda vedado el acceso'
Facultar: to empower/authorize — grants legal capacity to act: 'el reglamento le faculta para...'
Preceptuar/prescribir: to prescribe/mandate — used in legislation for obligatory norms
Estipular: to stipulate in a contract or agreement: 'tal como estipula el artículo 5'
Tipificar: to classify an action as a specific legal offense: 'el delito tipificado en el artículo...'
notes: Vedar is more absolute and formal than prohibir — often in constitutional or treaty language
Facultar is specifically about granting legal capacity/power — not the same as 'permitir'
Prescribir also means 'to expire' (a right or claim) — context is critical
Estipular collocates with contract/agreement terms and introduces specific conditions
examples: La Constitución veda cualquier forma de discriminación por razón de sexo, raza o religión. (The Constitution forbids any form of discrimination on grounds of sex, race or religion.)
Dicho reglamento faculta al director para adoptar las medidas urgentes que estime oportunas. (Said regulation empowers the director to adopt the urgent measures he deems appropriate.)
El contrato estipula que el pago deberá efectuarse dentro de los treinta días siguientes a la entrega. (The contract stipulates that payment must be made within thirty days of delivery.)

El artículo 248 del Código Penal tipifica como delito la falsificación de documentos oficiales. (Article 248 of the Penal Code classifies the falsification of official documents as a criminal offence.)

Diminutives & Augmentatives (pragmatic f.rule: Spanish diminutives (-ito/-ita, -illo/-illa) and augmentatives (-ón/-ona, -azo/-aza) go far beyond indicating size. At C1/C2, they encode pragmatic values: affection, irony, mitigation, intensification, and pejorative connotation. The same base word can have radically different pragmatic force depending on suffix, context, and region.
formation: Diminutive -ito/-ita: most common, neutral diminutive or affectionate: libro → librito
Diminutive -illo/-illa: slight pejorative or trivializing nuance: asunto → asuntillo
Augmentative -ón/-ona: big, intensified, often pejorative: hombre → hombrón (big man); also intensifying: buenón
Augmentative -azo/-aza: excellence/intensity OR pejorative large: golpe → golpazo; also 'what a [noun]!': exitazo
uses: -ito for mitigation/politeness: 'espera un momentito' (softer request than 'un momento')
-ito for irony: 'qué listo-ito' (how clever — sarcastic)
-illo for trivialization: 'ese asuntillo' (that little matter — dismissive)
-azo for excellence: '¡Qué golazo!' (What a great goal!); or intensification: 'un frío que pela, un friazo'
-ón for intensity (often pejorative): 'solterón' (confirmed bachelor, pejorative); 'grandullón' (big and clumsy)
notes: Regional variation is strong: -ito dominates in Latin America; -illo is more common in Spain
Pragmatic nuance can only be read in context — no suffix has a single fixed meaning
Some diminutives are lexicalized and have lost productive meaning: 'bolsillo' is just 'pocket', not 'small bag'
In formal/legal writing, diminutives and augmentatives are avoided — their appearance marks spoken register
examples: ¿Me dejas un momentito? (Can you give me just a moment? — diminutive as mitigation/politeness)

Ese asuntillo que mencionaste ayer puede tener consecuencias más graves de lo que parece. (That little matter you mentioned yesterday may have more serious consequences than it seems. — -illo trivializing, contrast with reality)
¡Vaya exitazo ha tenido esa campaña! (What a huge success that campaign has had! — -azo for intensified positive)
No le hagas caso: es un bocazas que dice lo primero que se le ocurre. (Don't pay attention to him: he's a big-mouth who says whatever comes to mind first. — augmentative pejorative)

Gerund & Infinitive.rule: This category covers gerund and infinitive uses that don't fall neatly into cause, consequence, means, or condition — including gerund of time (simultaneity), gerund of means in scientific/procedural writing, compound gerund for temporal ordering, and the contrast between gerund and subordinate clauses expressing manner. The core principle: Spanish gerunds are adverbial (they modify the verb), never adjectival (they cannot modify nouns).
Gerund & Infinitive.structure: Gerund (adverbial, modifying the main verb) | Infinitive (nominal or verbal complement)
formation: Gerund of time/simultaneity: verb of motion or activity + gerund (llegó corriendo, salió llorando)
Gerund of means (scientific/procedural): gerund at clause boundary indicating method (analizando X, se obtuvo Y)
Gerund vs. manner clause: 'estudiando' (gerund, compact) = 'mientras estudia/estudiaba' (clause, explicit)
Infinitive as subject: 'Estudiar es importante' — gerund NOT used as noun subject in standard Spanish
Infinitive after prepositions: 'antes de salir', 'al llegar', 'para entender' — never gerund after prepositions (except 'en')
uses: Gerund of time: expresses an action simultaneous with or immediately following the main verb
Scientific/procedural gerund: method or instrument — 'comparando los datos, se concluye que...'
Contrast gerund vs. clause: gerund is more formal and compact; subordinate clause is more explicit
Infinitive as subject: Spanish uses infinitive where English might use '-ing': 'Fumar es malo'
Infinitive after 'al': 'al llegar' = upon arriving — temporal with immediate sequence
notes: Spanish does NOT use gerund as a noun (subject/object): *'el estudiando es difícil' is WRONG; use infinitive: 'el estudiar / estudiar es difícil'
After almost all prepositions, use INFINITIVE not gerund: 'después de llegar' NOT *'después de llegando'
Exception: 'en + gerund' is acceptable in formal/literary contexts: 'en llegando al destino...'
Gerund after verbs of perception (ver, oír, sentir) marks an ongoing action perceived in progress: 'la vi saliendo del edificio'
examples: Entró al despacho dando un portazo, sin saludar a nadie. (He entered the office slamming the door, without greeting anyone. — simultaneous)

Analizando las variables de forma individual, se observa que cada una contribuye de manera diferenciada al resultado. (By analysing the variables individually, one observes that each contributes differently to the result. — procedural means)
Al revisar los documentos, el auditor detectó varias inconsistencias. (Upon reviewing the documents, the auditor detected several inconsistencies. — al + infinitive, immediate sequence)
Fumar en espacios cerrados está prohibido por ley. (Smoking in enclosed spaces is prohibited by law. — infinitive as subject, NOT gerund)
La vi saliendo del edificio justo cuando yo llegaba. (I saw her leaving the building just as I was arriving. — perception verb + gerund)

Formal Vocabulary.rule: C1/C2 Spanish requires mastery of a broad formal lexical register used in academic, legal, journalistic, and institutional writing. This includes formal synonyms for common verbs and nouns, collocations specific to formal prose, verbs of intellectual activity, assessment, and consequence, as well as register-appropriate connector choice. The key skill is not just knowing the formal word but choosing it when it is the right register match.
formation: Formal verb pairs: ocurrir → acontecer/acaecer; hacer → llevar a cabo/efectuar/realizar; decir → señalar/manifestar/sostener/afirmar
Formal nouns: problema → problemática; resultado → consecuencia/derivación/corolario; razón → fundamento/justificación
Formal adjectives: importante → relevante/significativo/trascendental; claro → patente/manifiesto/palmario
Formal collocations: llevar a cabo, poner de manifiesto, dar lugar a, tener en cuenta, en el marco de, a raíz de
Verbs of intellectual activity: analizar, examinar, constatar, corroborar, refutar, contrastar, cotejar
uses: Academic/research writing: prefer 'efectuar un análisis' over 'hacer un análisis'
Legal texts: 'en el supuesto de que', 'a los efectos de', 'con arreglo a', 'de conformidad con'
Journalistic/institutional: 'dar cuenta de', 'poner de relieve', 'hacer patente', 'poner de manifiesto'
Verbs of assessment: evaluar, ponderar, valorar, estimar — each with specific collocational behavior
Register distinction in connectors: empero (archaic concession), mas (literary 'but'), antes bien (correction/contrary to expectation)
notes: Formal vocabulary is not better than neutral vocabulary — it is appropriate or inappropriate depending on context
Overcrowding a text with formal synonyms creates pomposity, not sophistication
Key principle: use formal vocabulary when the genre/register demands it (legal brief, academic article), not as a default
Fixed formal collocations cannot be broken up: 'llevar a cabo' works; *'llevar esto a cabo antes' is marked
Register-sensitive connectors: 'mas' (literary but, no accent) ≠ 'más' (more); 'antes bien' introduces a corrective/contrary assertion
examples: El informe llevó a cabo un análisis exhaustivo de las causas estructurales del fenómeno. (The report carried out an exhaustive analysis of the structural causes of the phenomenon.)
Los resultados ponen de manifiesto la necesidad de revisar el marco normativo vigente. (The results highlight the need to review the current regulatory framework.)

De conformidad con lo establecido en el artículo 7, el plazo comenzará a computarse desde la notificación. (In accordance with what is established in article 7, the period will begin to run from notification.)

Cabe señalar, no obstante, que los datos disponibles son insuficientes para extraer conclusiones definitivas. (It should be noted, however, that the available data is insufficient to draw definitive conclusions.)

La propuesta fue rechazada, mas no por razones técnicas sino por consideraciones de índole política. (The proposal was rejected, but not for technical reasons but for considerations of a political nature. — 'mas' literary concessive)

Idiomatic Structures & Fixed Expressions.rule: C1/C2 Spanish requires knowledge of idiomatic and fixed expressions that cannot be decoded word-by-word, including pronominal verbs with idiomatic meaning, fixed expressions using hacerse/tornarse/volverse for change-of-state, impersonal constructions in formal contexts, and 'se' accidental in set phrases. These expressions are highly idiomatic and must be learned as units.
Idiomatic Structures & Fixed Expressions.structure: Fixed expression (invariable or with limited inflection) | Pronominal verb + complement
formation: Hacerse + adjective/noun: to become (through gradual process or effort): hacerse rico, hacerse cargo
Volverse + adjective: to become (involuntary change): volverse loco, volverse agresivo
Tornarse + adjective: formal/literary 'to become': la situación se tornó insostenible
Ponerse + adjective: sudden/emotional change of state: ponerse nervioso, ponerse rojo
Fixed impersonal constructions: es menester, cabe señalar, conviene recordar, es preciso
Formal fixed phrases: poner de manifiesto, dar lugar a, hacer las veces de, tener cabida, salir a la luz
uses: Hacerse: implies effort, willingness, or gradual process: 'se hizo famoso con el tiempo'
Volverse: involuntary transformation, often negative: 'se volvió introvertido tras el accidente'
Tornarse: literary/formal equivalent of volverse: 'la negociación se tornó tensa'
Ponerse: sudden or emotional/physical change: 'se puso pálido al oír la noticia'
Quedarse + adjective: resulting state after an event: 'se quedó sin palabras', 'quedarse en blanco'
Formal impersonals as discourse organizers: cabe, conviene, es menester — signal academic/formal register
notes: The four change-of-state verbs (hacerse/volverse/tornarse/ponerse) are NOT interchangeable — choice depends on type of change
Quedarse + adjective signals a resulting/residual state: 'quedarse helado' (to be left speechless/frozen)
Formal impersonals (cabe, conviene, es menester) require infinitive, NOT que + subjunctive: 'cabe señalar que' NOT 'cabe que se señale'
Many fixed expressions involve 'dar': dar lugar a (to give rise to), dar cuenta de (to account for), dar fe de (to attest to)
Salir a la luz (to come to light) is a key journalistic fixed expression for revelations
examples: Tras años de esfuerzo, se hizo un nombre en el sector financiero internacional. (After years of effort, he made a name for himself in the international financial sector. — hacerse, gradual/effortful)
La situación se tornó insostenible a medida que aumentaban las presiones sobre la dirección. (The situation became untenable as pressure on management increased. — tornarse, formal/literary)
Se quedó en blanco cuando le preguntaron por los detalles del contrato. (He went blank when asked about the details of the contract. — quedarse, resulting state)
Cabe recordar que el plazo de presentación de candidaturas vence el próximo viernes. (It should be remembered that the deadline for submitting applications expires next Friday. — formal impersonal)
Los documentos que salieron a la luz durante la investigación revelaron la magnitud del fraude. (The documents that came to light during the investigation revealed the scale of the fraud.)
La aprobación de la ley dio lugar a un intenso debate parlamentario. (The passing of the law gave rise to an intense parliamentary debate. — dar lugar a)
